articleContent.title: Arpeggio: 13th in A# (Shape: E)
articleContent.content:
# Arpeggios: 13th in A# (Shape: E)

An arpeggio is a musical technique where notes in a chord are played or sung in sequence, rather than simultaneously. In this particular arpeggio, we will focus on the 13th chord in A# (A#13). The shape we will be using to play this arpeggio is based on the E chord shape.

## Notes and Intervals:
- A# (Root)
- E# (5th)
- G# (b7th)
- C (9th)
- D# (11th)
- F# (13th)

By building the A#13 chord with the E shape, you get these notes in the arpeggio, creating a rich and jazzy sound due to the extended 9th, 11th, and 13th intervals.

## Genre and Musical Flavor:
The A#13 arpeggio with the E shape is commonly used in jazz, fusion, and R&B music. It adds a sophisticated and colorful flavor to chord progressions and solos. The inclusion of extended intervals gives a sense of tension and release, creating a complex and interesting sound.

## Songs featuring A#13 Arpeggio with E Shape:
1. "So What" by Miles Davis
2. "Cantaloupe Island" by Herbie Hancock
3. "Still D.R.E." by Dr. Dre ft. Snoop Dogg

These songs showcase the versatility and musicality of the A#13 arpeggio with the E shape, demonstrating its applications across different genres and styles.
